page.title: 06Belvedere House, Banstead
page.content: Belvedere House is marked as a hospital and lies to the south of Banstead in Holly Lane. It is in fact a home of 62 residents belonging to the Royal Alfred Seamen Society. Half of these residents are able bodied and live in rooms on the first floor which are known as cabins. Downstairs there are 8 wards of various sizes and an intensive care room. The society was formed in 1867 to found a hospital for worn out and disabled sailors and was given Royal permission to name itself after His Royal Highness Prince Alfred, Duke of Edinburgh. The original hospital was at Belvedere in Kent and the name was retained when it moved to Banstead in 1978. It now opens its doors to naval officers and ratings of the Royal Navy and their widows as well as retired merchant seamen.
